metadata.title: Dysphagia Assessment  In-depth  Bedside Swallow Examination (Adults)
synonyms: swallowing disorder assessment  in-depth  bedside swallow examination (adults)
bedside swallow examination, in-depth (adults): swallowing disorder assessment
description: The bedside swallow examination (BSE) is a noninstrumental assessment of swallowing performed by a speech-language pathologist (SLP) at a patient’s bedside (if the patient is an inpatient) or in the SLP’s office (if the patient is an outpatient).(1) BSEs are performed in both adult and pediatric patients. The purposes of a BSE are to:
Determine the need for further instrumental examination of the swallow(1)
Identify the type of treatment to which the patient might best respond(1)
indications: A BSE is indicated in all patients with suspected dysphagia

Indicated if a patient fails an initial dysphagia assessment by nursing (for detailed information on initial dysphagia assessment/nursing swallow screen, see Clinical Review...Dysphagia Assessment: Initial Bedside Screening ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709036)
Indicated if a patient presents with history of unexplained weight loss with no known diagnosis
Indicated for patients with subjective complaints of difficulty swallowing(2)
Sometimes indicated as part of a comprehensive neurological workup if a physician is attempting to determine a patient’s underlying diagnosis(3)

Swallowing G-code set.G8996: Swallowing functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Swallowing G-code set.G8997: Swallowing functional limitation, projected goal status, at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Swallowing G-code set.G8998: Swallowing functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy/ end of reporting on limitation

reimbursement: Reimbursement for procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this procedure Indications for procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Prior to the administration of the BSE, ensure that the patient is not on NPO status (nothing per oral) awaiting a procedure; check with patient’s nurse prior to start of examination

Review patient’s chart and speak to the patient’s nurse and family members, if possible, to rule out food allergies; if a patient has a food allergy, ensure that the food and liquid used in trials for the BSE do not contain these allergens(1)
In addition to food allergies, be aware of any religious or cultural dietary restrictions prior to giving the patient anything to eat(14)

Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (e.g., airborne, droplet, contact precautions)(14)
Stay with the patient during the entirety of the BSE. Do NOT leave the patient alone with food or drink until the BSE is complete and the patient is determined to be safe for oral feeding(14)
Any clinician performing a BSE should be trained in the Heimlich maneuver as well as CPR, as choking is a possible complication of a BSE(14)

indications for procedure: Dysphagia Dysphagia refers to difficulty swallowing and/or a swallowing disorder(4,5) Complications of dysphagia include malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration and aspiration pneumonia, and death(4,6,7) There are two types of dysphagia(5) –Oropharyngeal dysphagia(5,8,9) -Dysphagia involving the oral and/or pharyngeal phase of swallowing -Dysphagia that affects the oral phase only is referred to as oral dysphagia(10) -Dysphagia that affects the pharyngeal phase only is referred to as pharyngeal dysphagia(10) -Dysphagia that affects both oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow is referred to as oropharyngeal dysphagia(10) -Symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia include choking and/or coughing while eating and/or drinking, pocketing food in the cheeks, and loss of food or liquid from the mouth while attempting to swallow(4,8) –Esophageal dysphagia  (5,8,9) -Dysphagia resulting from an impairment of the esophagus or lower esophageal sphincter -Patients generally report symptoms such as regurgitation or heartburn(4,8,9) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

Patients at risk for dysphagia Patients with the following diagnoses and risk factors are at an elevated risk for dysphagia: –Cervical osteophytes(5) –Ear, nose, throat, or maxillofacial surgery(1) –Advanced age(7,9,11) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in elderly patients, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Older Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708995) –Head and neck cancer (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with head and neck cancer, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Patients with Head and Neck Cancer ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709050)(4,5) –Infection(5) -Botulism(5) -Diphtheria(5) -Lyme disease(5) -Syphilis(5)  –Neurological disease(1,4,5) -Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)(5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708986) -Brainstem tumor(5) -Stroke(4,5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with stroke, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Post-Stroke ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708770) -Dementia(4) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with dementia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Dementia ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708935) -Dermatomyositis/polymyositis(5) -Multiple sclerosis(4,5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708991) -Myasthenia gravis(5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in adult patients with myasthenia gravis, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Myasthenia Gravis in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709053) -Muscular dystrophy(5) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with muscular dystrophy, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Myotonic Dystrophy in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709072 and Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Oculopharyngeal Muscular Dystrophy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709071) -Paraneoplastic syndrome (collective signs and symptoms caused by material released from a tumor or in reaction to a tumor)(5) -Parkinson disease(4,5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with Parkinson disease, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Parkinson Disease ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T708934) -Postpolio syndrome(5) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in post-polio  syndrome, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Post-Polio  Syndrome ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709062) -Sarcoidosis (the growth of tiny groups of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body) (5) -Traumatic brain injury(5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of traumatic brain injury, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic) –Prior cervical or esophageal surgery(1,5) –Prolonged endotracheal intubation(11) –Zenker’s diverticulum(5,9)

Clinical features of dysphagia/signs and symptoms of aspiration Choking(4,6,8,11) Complaint of food “sticking” in the throat(6,8) Coughing (before, during, or after swallowing)(4,6,8,11) Difficulty initiating the swallow(8) Drooling(8,11) Holding food in the mouth(4,8) Oral or nasal regurgitation of food or liquid(6,11) Oxygen desaturation/lower SpO 2 levels(12,13,14) Shortness of breath/increased work of breathing(4) Watery eyes after swallowing Wet voice(4,6,8,11,15)

there is no standardized protocol for a: Hospitals, clinics, and SLPs develop protocols specific to and appropriate for their patient populations
A physician order is required prior to initiating a BSE

contraindications precautions to examina: Prior to the administration of the BSE, ensure that the patient is not on NPO status (nothing per oral) awaiting a procedure; check with patient’s nurse prior to start of examination

Review patient’s chart and speak to the patient’s nurse and family members, if possible, to rule out food allergies; if a patient has a food allergy, ensure that the food and liquid used in trials for the BSE do not contain these allergens(1)
In addition to food allergies, be aware of any religious or cultural dietary restrictions prior to giving the patient anything to eat(14)

Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (e.g., airborne, droplet, contact precautions)(14)
Stay with the patient during the entirety of the BSE. Do NOT leave the patient alone with food or drink until the BSE is complete and the patient is determined to be safe for oral feeding(14)
Any clinician performing a BSE should be trained in the Heimlich maneuver as well as CPR, as choking is a possible complication of a BSE(14)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Does the patient have a diagnosis that places him or her at an elevated risk for dysphagia?(2) -Is the patient NPO? If so, how long has the patient been NPO?(14)

course of treatment.medical management: Note current and previous medical management of diagnosis; do any of the medical treatments place patient at an elevated risk for dysphagia? Chemotherapy and radiation therapy might result in xerostomia (dry mouth);(11) xerostomia frequently is associated with dysphagia(9,11) Current or previous ear, nose, throat, maxillofacial, cervical, or esophageal surgery/procedures(1,5)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Review patient’s medical record to determine if a BSE or an instrumental evaluation of the swallow was completed during a previous hospital stay or outpatient visit(14)
Review neuroimaging (MRI and CT scan) results
Review patient’s recent chest X-rays;  be aware of increasing infiltrates in the lungs
Bed-bound  patients who have aspirated food or liquids during swallowing might present with heterogeneous

opacities on chest Xrays;  the material generally is aspirated into the posterior segments of the upper lobes of the lung or into the superior and posterior basal segments of the lower lobes of the lungs(16)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help Patients with a prior history of dysphagia might already be on an altered diet prior to admission(17) Ask patient and/or caregiver what types of food or drink the patient prefers and/or avoids at home(17)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had therapy for dysphagia and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)(14) -with specific foods? -with specific meals? -only halfway through meals? -when he or she is fatigued? -when he or she is distracted or having a meal with a group of people?(7)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms -For patients who complain of difficulty swallowing, what exactly is the problem with swallowing? -Does food stick in the throat?(9) -Does the patient cough and/or choke while eating or drinking? -Is there pain associated with swallowing?
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -When did the symptoms of dysphagia first present?(3) -How frequently does the patient experience symptoms of dysphagia?(3)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Does difficulty swallowing saliva and/or secretions interfere with the patient’s ability to sleep? -Document number of wakings/night
history of present illness.respiratory status: Patients with a compromised respiratory status are at higher risk of complications due to dysphagia(1,14,17) -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula? -Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube? -When the patient has an uncapped tracheostomy tube, subglottic pressure is reduced and the strength of the swallow is altered(14) -Complete Passy-Muir  tracheostomy and ventilator swallowing and speaking valve evaluation prior to BSE. For detailed information on assessment and treatment with a Passy-Muir  valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy &T708919 -Does the patient require ventilator support?Patient should be extubated prior to completion of a BSE; a patient who has oral endotracheal intubation is not a candidate for a BSE or oral feeding -Patients who previously required ventilator support/were orally intubated are at an elevated risk for aspiration during swallowing(14,20,21) -Although BSEs often are performed for patients who have recently been extubated, the clinician should also consider completing an instrumental examination of swallowing for these patients. Patients often experience laryngeal injuries (e.g., edema, ulceration, granulation, abnormal vocal fold mobility) associated with intubation/extubation and are at higher risk for silent aspiration, which cannot be detected on a BSE(22,23,24) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of oropharyngeal dysphagia?(14)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient or caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -With whom does patient live (e.g., family, caregivers)?(1) -Patients with dysphagia might need to eat their meals alone or in silence to prevent distraction, which might increase risk of aspiration -Patients who will require an altered diet might require assistance with food preparation from family members and/or caregiver(1) -Is the patient receiving nutritional supplements orally or nonorally?(14) -Is there a feeding tube present?(1,14) -Does the patient require feeding assistance at home?(1,7)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Trials of food and liquid -As the final step in a BSE, the SLP provides the patient with trials of food and/or liquid per specific hospital protocol(1,3,13,14) -If the SLP deems the patient to be unsafe for oral feeding trials after completing the initial parts of the assessment (listed above), the portion of the BSE in which food trials are given should be omitted(3) -Refer to specific hospital protocol for specifics regarding food and liquid trials -Water is pH neutral and should be used for initial trials as it will cause the least harm if aspirated(17) -Authors of a 2008 literature review of noninstrumental swallow examinations found that the most commonly reported assessment with stroke patients was some version of the water-swallow  test(3) -In each of the water-swallow  tests, a measured amount of water is provided to the patient(3) -The patient is observed during and after administration of the water trial; if he or she develops any signs or symptoms of aspiration during the trial or within a minute after the trial, the patient is considered to have a swallowing impairment(3) -The specificity (i.e., the accuracy of these tests in identifying aspiration) of these tests generally is higher than the sensitivity (i.e., the ability of these tests to detect aspiration)(3) -The water-swallow  tests might fail to identify a large percentage of patients who aspirate; however, when a water-swallow  test indicates swallowing impairment, videofluoroscopic examination of the swallow generally confirms the presence of aspiration -This seems to be due to the large percentage of patients who aspirate silently(3)  -Appropriate trials -Liquids -Thin liquids(14) -Nectar-thick  liquids(14) -Honey-thick  liquids(14) -Solids -Puree(14) -Soft solids(14) (soft fruit, cooked vegetables, soft bread, pasta) -Hard solids(14) (crackers) -During food and liquid trials, the SLP observes and palpates the patient’s swallow(14) -Does the patient have difficulty taking the bolus from the spoon, cup, or straw?(1) -If the patient loses significant amounts of food or liquid while attempting to eat or drink, adaptive cups and/or utensils might be necessary(14) -Is the patient able to keep the food in his or her mouth?(1) -Is mastication of the solid foods adequate and efficient?(1,14) -If the patient is using more energy to chew the food than he or she is getting from the food itself, solid foods might not be appropriate -Does the patient continue to chew/manipulate bolus until the swallow is complete, or does he or she stop too early, leaving the bolus in the oral cavity?(1) -If the patient does not persist with bolus formation and anterior-posterior  propulsion of the bolus, he or she might not be appropriate for oral nutrition -When a bolus is left in the oral cavity during the meal, the patient is at risk of aspirating this bolus at a later point -Does the patient trigger the pharyngeal swallow in a timely manner?(13) -The entire swallow should take place within 1 second -Patients with very impaired swallow function might not be able to initiate a pharyngeal swallow at all(14) -Does the patient have adequate laryngeal excursion to palpation?(13) -Does the patient require multiple swallows per bolus?(14) -Multiple swallows per bolus might indicate reduced base of tongue strength and/or residue in the valleculae/pharynx -Does the patient have signs and symptoms of aspiration?(1) -Cervical auscultation(3,13,14) -A technique in which the SLP places a stethoscope against the larynx and listens to the patient’s pre-swallow  breath sounds, swallowing, and post-swallow  breathing for signs of aspiration (such as pooling of secretions or wetness on the vocal cords)CervicalT709100 -Do the signs and symptoms of aspiration occur before, during, or after the swallow response? -Do the patient’s vital signs change as a result of the apparent aspiration? -Monitor respiratory rate, heart rate, SpO 2, and blood pressure for significant changes(3,14) -Observe the patient’s face and skin color; if the patient’s skin turns blue or red, this might be a sign of aspiration(14) -Is the patient able to recover to baseline status following signs and symptoms of aspiration?Although many formal protocols have been developed to guide the clinician during a BSE, none has been found to be 100% accurate or consistent in identifying dysphagia or detecting aspiration.(27) Additionally, no one formal BSE has been identified as being superior to others(27) -Cough Test(18) -Developed by researchers as a bedside screening test for silent aspiration -Patients inhaled a mist of citric acid-physiologic  saline orally for a period of 1 minute using an ultrasonic nebulizer -During inhalation, the patients were observed and the number of coughs were recorded  -Patients who had 5 or more coughs were considered to have a normal response/not at risk for silent aspiration -Patients who had fewer than 5 coughs were considered to be at risk for silent aspiration -Silent aspiration was then confirmed or ruled out with an instrumental assessment of dysphagia (videofluoroscopy or videoendoscopy) -Researchers concluded that the Cough Test was a reliable, useful screening test for silent aspiration and could be used in conjunction with a modified water swallow test to identify patients with dysphagia and those at risk for silent aspirationa clinical test battery developed by researchers and intended to assist the SLP in generating a treatment plan(3) -Not designed to detect dysphagia or determine its severity(3) -Authors of the study that attempted to validate the DDB concluded that their results were inadequate for clinical purposes and that use of the DDB would not replace the information gathered by a VFSS(3)a clinical assessment developed in Australia(3) -Intended to assess dysphagia in neurologic populations(1) -Measures 24 swallowing-related  skills using a 5- and 10-point  rating scale(3) -The authors of the original study as well as authors of other, more recent studies have found the MASA to have good reliability and validity as a noninstrumental bedside assessment of dysphagia(3) -The MASA has not been evaluated in nonneurologic dysphagia patients and therefore should not be used to evaluate these patients(3)Developed  for patients with neurological conditions; performed at bedside using various foods of different viscosities and volumes(27)A test protocol that requires the patient to drink an entire 3-oz (90 cc) of water from a cup or with a straw using sequential swallows without stopping. If the patient is observed coughing or choking during or immediately after completion of drinking, this is considered a failure of the test and an indication of dysphagia.(27) Authors of a systematic review of bedside screening methods for oropharyngeal dysphagia reported that the 3-oz Water Swallowing Test has excellent sensitivity, but low specificity (i.e., a negative result usually is accurate and the patient does not have dysphagia; however, a positive result/failure of this test does not always necessarily correlate with actual presence of dysphagia)(27) –In a study conducted in the United States with 62 patients with acute stroke, researchers found that spontaneous swallow frequency analysis (SFA) had high potential to identify dysphagia among patients with acute stroke. In this study, all patients were screened for dysphagia according to the hospital’s stroke assessment protocol. Additionally, researchers used a miniature microphone attached to the patient’s anterolateral neck just below the cricoid cartilage to record spontaneous swallows over the course of 30 minutes. The recordings were analyzed by an acoustic software program, and spontaneous swallow frequency rate was calculated as swallows per minute (SPM). Researchers found a significant difference between SPM among those patients identified as having dysphagia and those without. For the patients with dysphagia, SPM was 0.23 and for the nondysphagic group it was 0.56. Researchers recommended further research into this method as a dysphagia screening tool(25) –Trial of compensatory strategies -During the portion of the BSE in which the SLP presents the patient with trials of food, it is appropriate for the SLP to attempt specific compensatory strategies in an effort to discover the type of therapy to which the patient will respond(13) -Alternating solids and liquids -Chin down -Downward pressure with the spoon to assist initiation of swallow response -Head tilt to the right or left -Head rotation to the right or left -Liquids given by spoon only -For detailed information on compensatory strategies used in dysphagia therapy, refer to Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Assess patient’s level of consciousness as well as his or her ability to follow directions(1,4,6,7,13,14) –Patients who are unable to maintain consciousness for the entire BSE might not be appropriate for oral nutrition and oral medication(14) –Method of communication(1) -During the BSE, it is appropriate to conduct a brief screening of the patient’s speech and language abilities(13) -It is important that a patient is able to communicate with the SLP during the BSE -The patient should be able to report pain or “sticking” sensations if they are experienced during the BSE -If the patient speaks a different language from that of the SLP, ensure a certified medical translator (not a member of the patient’s family) is present for BSEA laryngeal exam should be completed as part of every BSE.(2,14) Examination of the larynx might –Does the patient have a strong cough and throat clear?(13,14) -The patient must have a strong cough and throat clear to be a candidate for oral nutrition -If the patient does not have the ability to cough and clear his or her throat, he or she is unable to adequately protect the airway –Gag reflex(1,13,14) -Attempt to elicit patient’s gag reflex -A hypo-  or hyperactive gag reflex might indicate neurologic impairmentBriefly palpate patient’s larynx -Is there pain associated with palpation? -Is there swelling of the tissues surrounding the larynx? -Is the patient able to independently initiate a dry swallow? (i.e., swallow his or her own saliva) -Is there adequate laryngeal excursion?(1,13) -It is important for the patient to be able to initiate dry swallows in order for him or her to clear residue from the oral and/or pharyngeal cavities -The larynx might be difficult to palpate in patients with excess adipose neck tissue –Vocal fold function -Is the patient able to phonate? -If the patient is unable to phonate, this might indicate vocal fold dysfunction -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphonia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic -What is the vocal quality?(1,13,14) -Breathy -Harsh -Raspy -Wet (wet phonation is a clinical feature of dysphagia) -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphonia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic  -Is the patient able to sustain phonation? -If the patient is unable to sustain his or her phonation, this might indicate reduced lung function or impaired respiratory status -Are there pitch breaks in the patient’s voicing? Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Is the patient able to sit up and hold up his or her head?(1,4,6,14) -The patient should be able to sit upright at (or close to) 90° –If the patient is unable to maintain upright positioning, he or she might not be appropriate for oral nutrition(4,14)An extensive oral mechanism examination should be completed as part of everyAbnormalities of the buccal and facial muscles indicate damage to cranial nerve (CN) VII(1) -Is the face symmetrical at rest? -Is the face symmetrical while making movements (smiling, raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes)? -Are there any abnormal movements (twitching, spasms, grimacing)? -Is the patient able to manage his or her secretions?(6,14) -Is the patient’s facial sensation intact?(1) -The patient needs to have adequate sensation of the facial muscles to feel and retrieve any residue during a meal -Is the patient drooling or mouth breathing?(1,6) -Does the patient present with slurred speech/dysarthria?(1,17) -If patient presents with dysarthria, he or she might be appropriate for a full speech/language evaluation following completion of the BSE -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAbnormalities of the labial muscles indicate damage to CN VII(1,2) -Are the lips symmetrical at rest? -Are the lips symmetrical during movements? -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to completely seal his or her lips during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly(13) -Is strength normal? -Is the lip tissue healthy? -Is there any scarring or cleft? -Is the patient’s labial sensation intact?(1) -If a patient has reduced sensation of either or both of the lips, the patient is at risk for anterior loss or pocketing of the food on the side of reduced sensationAbnormalities of the tongue indicate damage to CN XII(1,2) -Is the tongue normal in appearance? -Any atrophy? -Any tremors present? -Any discolorations? -Any bleeding? -Patients with xerostomia as a result of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or medication side effects might present with dry, cracked tongue tissue or a white/yellow coating on the tongue -Is ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to reach his or her tongue to the hard palate during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly -Is the strength normal? -If patient presents with one-sided  weakness of tongue (or lips), he or she is more likely to have food become lodged or pocketed on the weaker side -Following food and liquid trials, examine weaker side of the oral cavity for residueAbnormalities of mandibular function indicate damage to CN V(1)  -Is the patient able to maintain jaw closure at rest? -Is ROM normal? -Adequate mandibular ROM is necessary for the patient to adequately masticate solid foods -Is strength normal? -Is the mandible structurally intact? -Patients with head and neck cancer (especially base of the tongue cancers) might have had reconstructive surgeries altering anatomy of the jaw –Hard palate  (2) -Is the hard palate intact? -Any signs of fistulas, fissures, or scarring? -Are the height and width normal? -Any prostheses present? -Is the coloration normal?Abnormalities of the soft palate (velum) indicate damage to CN XII(1,2) -Is the coloration normal (should be pink and white)? -Any signs of cleft or bifid uvula? -Does the palate elevate sufficiently and equally? -Use a flashlight to see to the back of the patient’s throat during sustained phonation of the syllable /a/ and repeated phonation of /a-a-a/(1) -Does the patient sound hyper-  or hyponasal during conversational speech? -Place a small mirror under the patient’s nose during production of nonnasal sounds; fogging or clouding might indicate nasal emission, which would indicate a referral to an otolaryngologist –Teeth  (2,13) -Are there any missing teeth? -Are the teeth in good repair? -Does the patient wear partial or full dentures? -If the patient is edentulous, inquire if the patient has dentures at home; if family is able to bring dentures in, reexamine mastication with dentures present -Patients who are edentulous might still be able to eat a regular diet; each patient is different -Is there a significant over-  or underbite?

contraindications precautions: Oral dysphagia, pharyngeal dysphagia, and oropharyngeal dysphagia(10) -If the SLP suspects esophageal dysphagia, a referral to gastroenterology is appropriate
Severity of dysphagia: Mild, moderate, severe, and profound
-Mild: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 23 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are spontaneously cleared; patient coughs appropriately to pharyngeal residue(10)
-Moderate: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 35 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are cleared given a cue; patient coughs to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue given a cue(10)

-Severe: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 510  seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are not able to be cleared; patient does not cough appropriately to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue and might have a wet, gurgly voice; also might have difficulty managing his or her own secretions(10) -Profound: term usually reserved for patients who present with no apparent swallow response, as well as minimal ability to protect the airway

Patients do not always fit into these categories of dysphagia severity; it is also appropriate for the SLP to classify a patient’s dysphagia with the labels minimal, mild-moderate,  and moderate-severe(10)

If the SLP suspects any laryngeal/pharyngeal involvement (i.e., pharyngeal dysphagia) and/or aspiration, an instrumental evaluation of dysphagia should be completed for further diagnosis of the problem and appropriate determination of the treatment plan(2,10,14) -A BSE alone is not sufficient to identify all cases of aspiration; a BSE cannot detect silent aspiration (aspiration of food or liquids without overt signs and symptoms)(19) -In a study conducted in Denmark, researchers found that a fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES) was not superior to a clinical, noninstrumental examination of swallowing (i.e., BSE) in terms of the number of cases of aspiration pneumonia that developed in a group of patients with acquired brain injury (i.e., stroke, TBI, anoxia).(26)Over the course of 2 years, 138 patients from a national neurorehabilitation center were randomized into a FEES assessment group or a Facial-Oral  Tract Therapy (FOTT) assessment group. Decision to initiate oral intake for these patients was based entirely on the single assessment; none of these patients had both types of swallowing assessments. FOTT is comprehensive program that provides a structured assessment and treatment for disturbances of facial muscles, speech- and swallowing-related  jaw movements, breathing, swallowing, and the voice. The FOTT assessment is a clinical, noninstrumental examination of swallowing. Of the 138 patients included in the study, 16 developed pneumonia (4 FOTT/12 FEES); however, 9 were excluded from analysis because 6 developed pneumonia before oral intake was initiated and 3 had a clinical diagnosis of pneumonia but no radiological signs. Of the 7 included in analysis, 3 patients assessed by FOTT and 4 patients assessed by FEES developed aspiration pneumonia. For this reason, researchers concluded that there was no significant difference between the FOTT and FEES assessments; however, the sample size was very small, resulting in low sensitivity(26) -For detailed information on instrumental assessments of dysphagia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Modified Barium Swallow (Adults) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709046; Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Fiberoptic Endoscopic Evaluation of Swallowing (FEES) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709038; and Clinical Review… Dysphagia Assessment: Manometry ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709040
The recommendations for oral feeding generally are based on the severity of dysphagia and overall risk of aspiration(10)

Recommendations -Normal swallow: If the patient appears to have normal swallowing function, he or she is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid(10) -Minimal impairment: If the patient appears to have minimally impaired swallowing function, he or she is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the independent use of one or more compensatory strategies(10) -Mild impairment: If the patient appears to have mildly impaired swallowing function, he or she usually is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the use of one or more compensatory strategies; this type of patient generally requires cueing up to 10% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(10) -Mild-moderate  impairment: If the patient appears to have mildly-moderately  impaired swallowing function, the patient will require some modification of his or her diet and will require the use of one or more compensatory strategies; this type of patient generally requires cueing up to 25% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(10) -Moderate impairment: If the patient appears to have moderately impaired swallowing function, he or she will require modification of his or her diet, as well as direct supervision during meals; patient will require frequent cues to use one or more compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient might require nonoral nutritional and/or hydrational support(10) -Moderate-severe  impairment: If the patient appears to have moderate-severely  impaired swallowing function, the patient will require significant modification of his or her diet, as well as 1:1 assistance during meals with constant cues to use compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient will require nonoral nutritional and/or hydrational support(10) -Severe impairment: If the patient appears to have severely impaired swallowing function, he or she should be made NPO (nothing by mouth) with non-oral  means of nutritional and hydrational support; any food or liquid trials should be given by the SLP only during therapy sessions(10) -Profound impairment: The patient with a profound impairment of swallowing will not be appropriate for any food, liquid, or medication by mouth; patient is generally not appropriate for therapeutic trials of food or liquid with SLP; the
patient’s oral cavity should be aggressively cleaned and suctioned by nursing every 23 hours to prevent infection

assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the successful treatment of dysphagia(2) Referral to gastroenterologist for patients in whom esophageal dysphagia is suspected(2,13) Referral to neurologist for patients with dysphagia who do not have a known underlying diagnosis(2) Referral to pulmonologist for patients who appear to have poor respiratory status and/or function(2) Referral to otolaryngologist for patients with apparent vocal fold dysfunction(13) Referral to nutrition services/dietician for patients with poor oral intake or those at risk for malnutrition(2,14,15) Referral to physical and/or occupational therapy for patients with poor posture, difficulty sitting up in the bed or chair, or difficulty feeding themselves(2)
treatment summary: Goals of treatment for dysphagia include restoration of swallowing ability, mastery of compensatory strategies, and adequate nutritional and hydrational intake(2,6)
